schema.name: mAdminState
schema.summary: Set the administrative state of this configuration.
schema.label: Enable administrative state
schema.hoverhelp: <p>Set the administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set the check box.</li><li>To make inactive, clear the check box.</li></ul>
schema.description: <p>The administrative state of the configuration.</p><ul><li>To make active, set to enabled.</li><li>To make inactive, set to disabled.</li></ul>
A descriptive summary for the configuration.
schema.summary: Enter a descriptive summary for the configuration.
schema.name: UserSummary
BlockNonmanagementTraffic
schema.summary: Indicate whether to block nonmanagement traffic for invalid interface configuration.
schema.display: Block nonmanagement traffic for invalid interface configuration
schema.hoverhelp: <p>When at least one network interface has an invalid configuration, indicate whether to block nonmanagement traffic or allow all network traffic.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the appliance blocks nonmanagement traffic.</li><li>When disabled, the appliance allows all network traffic.</li></ul><p>For a production appliance, always enable this property. With this setting, the appliance supports only management traffic over Telnet, SSH, web management interfaces (WebGUI and Blueprint Console), and the XML management interface. Until you correct the problem, the appliance cannot accept and process client requests.</p>
schema.description: <p>When at least one network interface has an invalid configuration, whether to block nonmanagement traffic or allow all network traffic.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the appliance blocks nonmanagement traffic.</li><li>When disabled, the appliance allows all network traffic.</li></ul><p>For a production appliance, always enable this property. With this setting, the appliance supports only management traffic over Telnet, SSH, web management interfaces (WebGUI and Blueprint Console), and the XML management interface. Until you correct the problem, the appliance cannot accept and process client requests.</p>

schema.name: ICMPDisable

value.summary: Indicates whether to reply to ICMP echo requests.
value.name: Echo-Reply
value.description: Whether to reply to ICMP echo requests.

value.summary: Indicates whether to reply to ICMP timestamp requests.
value.name: Timestamp-Reply
value.description: Whether to reply to ICMP timestamp requests.

value.summary: Indicates whether to reply to ICMP information requests.
value.name: Info-Reply
value.description: Whether to reply to ICMP information requests.

value.summary: Indicates whether to reply to ICMP address mask requests.
value.name: Addressmask-Reply
value.description: Whether to reply to ICMP address map requests.

schema.summary: Indicate which ICMP replies to disable.
schema.description: Which Internet Control Message Protocol (ICMP) requests to disable the generation of ICMP reply messages.

schema.name: ECNDisable
schema.summary: Indicate whether to disable ECN TCP indication.
schema.description: Whether to disable the generation of ECN-capable TCP sessions. By default, TCP sessions are ECN enabled.

schema.name: DestinationRouting
schema.summary: Indicate how the appliance determines the route to return the response to the originating client.
schema.hoverhelp: <p>Indicate how the appliance determines the route to return the response to the originating client. Enable destination-based routing only if an upgrade disables existing connectivity.</p><ul><li>When enabled, interface selection is based on the best path to the client, irrespective of the service or receiving interface.</li><li>When disabled, interface selection is based on the interface that is bound to the address of the service that generated the response.</li></ul>
schema.description: <p>How the appliance determines the route to return the response to the originating client. The route to return the response is the outbound packet. The originating client is the destination of the outbound packet.</p><ul><li>When enabled, interface selection is based on the best path to the client, irrespective of the service or receiving interface. The best path is determined by static routes that are bound to the available interfaces. <p><b>Note:</b> Destination-based routing is for compatibility with an earlier version only. Enable destination-based routing only if an upgrade disables existing connectivity.</p></li><li>When disabled, the default, interface selection is based on the interface that is bound to the address of the service that generated the response. <ul><li>If the service is bound to a single address, responses are routed through the interface that is assigned to that address.</li><li>If the service is bound to multiple addresses, responses are routed through the receiving interface instead of the interface for the service that generated the response.</li></ul></li></ul>

schema.name: AllowCrosstalkOnSubnet
schema.summary: Indicate whether to allow packets from a wrong interface when both interfaces are on the same subnet.
schema.hoverhelp: Indicate whether to allow packets from a wrong interface when both interfaces are on the same subnet. Relax interface isolation when destination-routing is enabled.
schema.description: Whether to relax the restriction on interface isolation. As a security policy, the interface that receives a packet must be configured with the IP address that is the destination address of the packet. Enabling this option relaxes that restriction. The packet is allowed if the interface it arrives on contains an IP address in the same subnet as the destination address of the packet. Relax interface isolation when destination-routing is enabled.

schema.name: AllowAllCrosstalk
schema.summary: Indicate whether to allow packets from one interface that are destined for a service on another interface.
schema.description: Whether to allow interface isolation. By default the appliance refuses to accept a packet on an interface other than the one bound to the destination address of the packet. As a security policy, the interface that receives a packet must be configured with the IP address that is the destination address of the packet. Enabling interface isolation relaxes the restriction.

schema.name: TCPSYNRetries
schema.summary: Set the number of times to send a failed TCP SYN request.
schema.hoverhelp: Set the number of times the local system attempts to send a TCP SYN that receives no response. Enter a value in the range 1 - 32.
schema.description: The number of times the local system attempts to send a TCP SYN that receives no response. Enter a value in the range 1 - 32. The default value is 5.

schema.name: ArpRetries
schema.summary: Set the number of times to attempt a failed ARP request.
schema.hoverhelp: Set the number of times that the appliance attempts a failed ARP request. Enter a value in the range 1 - 64.
schema.description: The number of times that the appliance attempts a failed ARP request. Enter a value in the range 1 - 64. The default value is 8.

schema.name: ArpInterval
schema.summary: Set the interval between ARP attempts.
schema.hoverhelp: Set the interval between ARP attempts. The appliance waits the defined time before it tries a failed ARP request again. Enter a value in the range 500 - 5000.
schema.description: The interval between ARP attempts. The appliance waits the defined time before it tries a failed ARP request again. Enter a value in the range 500 - 5000. The default value is 500.

schema.name: ReversePathFiltering
schema.summary: Indicate whether to ignore incoming packets with a source address that the interface cannot route.
schema.hoverhelp: <p>Indicate whether to ignore incoming packets with a source address that the interface cannot route.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the interface ignores incoming packets with a source address that it cannot route.</li><li>When disabled, the interface accepts and processes incoming packets with a source address that it cannot route.</li></ul>
schema.description: <p>Whether incoming packets with a source address that cannot be routed by that interface are accepted and processed. Enabling this option effectively disables source routing because the appliance ignores such packets.</p><ul><li>When enabled, the interface ignores incoming packets with a source address that it cannot route.</li><li>When disabled, the default, the interface accepts and processes incoming packets with a source address that it cannot route.</li></ul>

schema.name: TCPWindowScaling
schema.summary: Indicate whether to enable TCP window scaling.
schema.hoverhelp: Indicate whether to enable TCP window scaling. Window scaling allows the negotiation of window sizes greater than 64 KB. Disabling this option might help to work around TCP systems that do not understand or misinterpret window scaling.
schema.description: Whether to enable TCP window scaling. Window scaling allows the negotiation of window sizes greater than 64 KB. Disabling this option might help to work around TCP systems that do not understand or misinterpret window scaling.

schema.name: EphemeralPortRange
schema.summary: Set the starting port for the ephemeral port range.
schema.hoverhelp: Set the starting port of the ephemeral port range. The appliance can use ephemeral ports in the range 10000 - 61000 to send data over TCP and UDP. You can define a subset of ephemeral ports to not be ephemeral ports. These ports are ephemeral ports in the range 10000 - 32768. The appliance always has control of the ephemeral ports in the range 32769 - 61000.
schema.description: The starting port of the ephemeral port range. The appliance can use ephemeral ports in the range 10000 - 61000 to send data over TCP and UDP. You can define a subset of ephemeral ports to not be ephemeral ports. These ports are ephemeral ports in the range 10000 - 32768. The appliance always has control of the ephemeral ports in the range 32769 - 61000.
